1.	The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Shield
Shield Packaging Co., Inc.s accidental release program for its facility applies a fully integrated Risk Management Program that incorporates all the required Prevention Program elements that include standard operating procedures (SOP), a written mechanical integrity program (MI) that covers the process equipment, and management of change (MOC) procedures that ensure safe equipment design, configuration and operation is maintained. Release prevention and risk management procedures that are consistently applied at the facility are discussed in the RMP resubmittal documentation. 
Shields Management Team has a demonstrated commitment to maintaining compliance with both OSHA PSM and EPA RMP Programs, which includes the assurance that personnel are trained and capable of following its SOPs in completing their duties onsite.  The General Manager creates and certifies a list of the trained and certified personnel that are knowledgeable and fully capable of carrying out the duties and responsibilities specified in Shields SOPs.  This list is maintained and updated as needed when personnel are added or removed during the year and recertified and revised at least annually. SOPs are also updated when required by management of changes during the year, and at least annually reviewed and revised as necessary to retain their currency to reflect up-to-date operations and safety as they pertain to plant processes for both manufacturing and maintenance.  
In the event of an accidental release, Shield has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) which includes coordination with local emergency responders from the Dudley and Webster Fire Departments. Shield personnel are trained to perform emergency shut-down procedures to stop or control a release, if it is safe to do so. These procedures include roles and responsibilities, emergency procedures, facility emergency equipment, communications in the event of

an emergency as well as emergency shutdown of RMP governed equipment and processes.  The EAP includes conducting emergency drills for both onsite and off-site responders at least annually to ensure that Shields employees and local responders are familiar with the facilitys written EAP and are ready and able to respond in case of emergencies and potential fires.
2.	The Shield facility and the regulated substances handled
Shield Packaging Co., Inc. (Shield) is a contract manufacturer and packager of consumer and commercial products. Shield manufacturing operations have been located at its 50 Oxford Avenue facility in Dudley, Massachusetts facility, since 1982. A Site Location Map is included in the RMP.  The facility is engaged in the business of compounding, blending, and packaging aerosol and liquid consumer products for, household and automotive/industrial applications. Approximately 45 full-time employees work at the Facility. Emergency contact information for this Facility is included in the Emergency Action Plan. All products made by Shield are made for its unaffiliated commercial customers. Shield does not sell or market anything it produces directly to retailers or public consumers.  
Shield blends ingredients to customer specifications, and packages the mixtures in consumer quantity packages  both aerosol (spray products) and non-aerosol products. EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations (40 CFR §68) and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR §1910.119) apply to batch processing at the facility including the filling and warehousing of the finished aerosol products (boxed and palletized). Shield currently has four aerosol propellants that are held in quantities greater than 10,000 pounds, in four above ground storage tanks (AST). The quantities exceed the EPA RMP and OSHA PSM threshold quantities. Propellants are stored as liquefied gas under pressure in designated tanks that were made and are maintained by Shield specifically for th

at purpose. The RMP regulated substances currently used at the facility include n-propane (A-108), isobutane (A-31), propane/butane blend (AB-70), and dimethyl ether (DME). The processes regulated under the Risk Management Plan and Process Safety Management programs include the storage of those propellants, the charging of aerosol cans with propellant, and the temporary storage of filled aerosol cans.
The propellants are delivered to the Facility by carefully selected vendors with nationally recognized safety programs. The tanker truck is off-loaded by trained personnel to the designated tank. The Tank numbers, overall tank sizes and contents of the four RMP above ground storage tanks are as follows:
	Tank LPG#17- 30,000-gallon total volume
	Tank LPG#18- 30,000-gallon total volume
	Tank LPG#16- 6,000-gallon total volume
	Tank LPG#15- 6,000-gallon total volume

3.	Shields accidental release prevention program and Program 3 prevention elements 
Shield Packaging Company Inc. (Shield) has a single Prevention Program that is used to support compliance with the RMP Program 3 process that entails batch processing to package and fill aerosol cans with our customers formulations and specified propellants. The "process" includes interconnected and co-located propellant storage tanks, supply piping, can filling and propellant charging stations, filled can testing, labelling and packaging and product storage prior to shipment to our customer defined distribution points. As such, the Shield facility is defined to be a single "process" for purposes of the RMP rule.   
Shields RMP Prevention Program implementation involves the same safeguards for all batch operations that includes each of the following elements: 
	Process Safety Information (PSI), 
	Process Hazard Analyses (PHA), 
	Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), 
	Training, 
	Mechanical Integrity (MI) program and procedures, 
	Management of Change (MOC) procedures,
	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR), 
	Compl

iance Audits,
	Incident Investigation,
	Employee Participation,
	Hot Work Permit Procedure,
	Contractors Safety Management

All of the elements of Shields RMP Prevention Program (listed above) are implemented comprehensively with respect to Shields operations manufacturing the different batches that are prepared for our different customers in our process.  Shields business and operations are customer order based.  As such Shield is a Make-to-order manufacturer.  Based on this business model, the facility carries very little additional inventory of raw materials, including propellants, above the needs to meet near-term customer order-based batch operations.  As that relates to the Aerosol propellants, by policy, training and oversite, all four (4) of propellant storage tanks, which are equipped with specially designed pressure relief valves, are never filled beyond the 80% of capacity level. When comparing a tank's "total volume" to its "fill capacity," the key difference is the safety factor that Shield (and the entire aerosol packaging industry) applies. Meaning that the "fill capacity" limit (? 80%) used by Shield is always less than the total tank volume. A portion of the tank is intentionally left empty to account for potential expansion or other safety concerns, like temperature fluctuations. The facility also holds very little inventory of finished goods as we strive to make and ship to meet customer needs with the least amount of holding finished products in storage prior to shipping.  Since Shields batch operations consists of only one process train, operated in a batch mode, every element of Shields prevention program, as described and managed through our RMP Program Procedures, apply to our RMP covered process and RMP regulated substances. 
4.	Shields Five-year accident history 
Shield has had no reportable releases of RMP regulated chemicals at the facility over the past 5 years. 
5.	Shields Emergency Response Program
In the event of an accid

ental release, Shield has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) which includes coordination with local emergency responders from the Dudley and Webster Fire Departments. Shield personnel are trained to perform emergency shut-down procedures to stop or control a release, if it is safe to do so. These procedures include roles and responsibilities, emergency procedures, facility emergency equipment, communications in the event of an emergency as well as emergency shutdown of RMP governed equipment and processes.  The EAP includes conducting emergency drills for both onsite and off-site responders at least annually to ensure that our employees and local responders are familiar with Shields EAP and how to respond in case of emergencies and potential fires.
6.	Shields planned changes to improve safety
The most recent process hazard analysis (PHA), conducted in January of 2024, was a Hazards and Operability Study (HAZOP).  Through this very thorough structured systematic review of its operations and risks, the Shield HAZOP Team identified recommendations and findings to improve process safety, and the PHA team categorized corrective operational and mechanical integrity issues as low, medium, or high priority. High priority improvements will be performed before lower priority issues.  Shield uses a system to track all recommendations and findings from our PHAs and audits to closure and completion.
Shields Management Team has a demonstrated commitment to maintaining compliance with both OSHA PSM and EPA RMP Programs which includes the assurance that personnel are trained and capable of following its SOPs in completing their duties onsite.  The General Manager creates and certifies a list of the trained and certified personnel that are knowledgeable and fully capable of carrying out the duties and responsibilities specified in Shields SOPs.  This list is maintained and updated as needed when personnel are added or removed during the year and recertified and revised at

least annually. SOPs are also updated when required by management of changes during the year, and at least annually reviewed and revised as necessary to retain their currency to reflect up-to-date operations and safety as they pertain to plant processes for both manufacturing and maintenance.  
This RMP Resubmission provides the most recent "review or revision" of Shields Program 3 prevention program elements, as required by 40 CFR § 68.190(b).  As Shield resubmits this RMP (based on the 5-year resubmission requirement), we are certifying that we have fully updated all nine sections of our RMP program based on our recently conducted RMP Program audit and Process Hazard Analysis (HAZOP) results and our ongoing continuous improvement commitment to process safety management and risk management programs.  Shield continues to integrate our RMP program and procedures to fully support our commitment to our continued safe operations of the Shield Packaging facility.

Added butane (CAS # 106-97-8) as a portion of the AB-70 mixture.
